nodes.bodyText:
It almost seems to me like this index is "really" just a min/max index (but not a MIN_EVER or MAX_EVER index) with the special sauce that you can optionally make it "permuted" (though the permutedness isn't essential to its semantics--like you could imagine an alternate history where we made this index without the permuted feature and then added that later).
But not sure if that's a compelling enough reason to name the indexes MIN and MAX

Hmm. Well, a VALUE index can do MIN and MAX, as they are at the ends of a range. I guess having no permutation could mean skip the secondary keyspace maintenance, but then the index isn't good for other kinds of queries.
I'm inclined to have the index reject things that aren't useful rather than just things that aren't possible. But maybe I'm not thinking about it right.

nodes.bodyText: Should this default to zero instead of throwing an error? IIUC, a permuted size of zero would mean that the secondary subspace on this index would be (group, value), i.e., it would have the same semantics as a MIN_EVER or MAX_EVER index except without the "ever" ness, which seems like a sensible default.
Yes, but a VALUE index can do that and more.

I think that this index would be better than a VALUE index if you wanted to list all of the extrema (by group), not just calculate the extremum for a single group. I suppose you could do that with a skip-scan on a VALUE index, though it wouldn't be as performant.

This could probably use an example, something like "if you had an index on field(c).groupBy(concatenateFields(a, b)) with a permute size of 1, then this would allow you to find the minimum of maximum value of c for each (a, b) pair, ordered by (a, c, b)". And it should probably say that you specify the number of columns to add to the end of the grouping index by using the PERMUTED_SIZE_OPTION.
Added

I think this is fine, but I wanted to walk through one edge case, just to be sure. Suppose there are two index entries with the same extremum value, and then there are two concurrent transactions, one which removes one record and one which removes the other. Then I think both updates will see that the extremum hasn't changed and choose not to update the extremum value in the permuted space. But whichever commits second will be failed with a conflict anyway because the range scanned to calculate the extremum will have been changed (by the other write), and so one of the two updates will fail with a conflict (and not corrupt the index).
I think that's right, anyway.

Should these two index types be added to PlannableIndexTypes.valueTypes? Maybe the fact that they have GroupingKeyExpressions as their root key expression makes it a little awkward, but it seems like the primary space on this index could be used to answer the same sets of queries as a VALUE index (on the wholeKey)

nodes.bodyText: Does this need to override canDeleteWhere and/or deleteWhere to delete items from the secondary subspace?
Yes, it does. Added.

I suppose in theory, I could see this also having:

A test where the grouping expression is zero columns
A test where the permuted size is zero
A test of delete where

I'm also fine with merging this without the first two tests. A test of delete where would probably be good to have

1 & 2 fail index validation, again on the principle that an index that doesn't do anything useful should be rejected.
Test for delete where included with that addition.
